author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Refuses for Now to Restore Biden Plan on Immigration Enforcement
description: A federal judge in Texas has blocked guidelines setting priorities for Immigrations and Customs Enforcement agents, saying they were at odds with the immigrations laws.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court handed Texas and Louisiana a temporary victory on Thursday, allowing a federal judge to block immigration enforcement guidelines issued by the Biden administration that he said allowed the release of undocumented immigrants with criminal records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: San Francisco Shines With New Museums, Restaurants and Parks
description: The city’s neighborhoods, from the Mission to Russian Hill and the Outer Sunset, are vibrant with packed restaurants and bars, and many are home to new parks and the return of in-person events.
content: Lately, it seems like the news headlines from San Francisco have been negative, from the city’s homelessness crisis and highly publicized recall elections to the area’s astronomical cost-of-living and worsening fire seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Lightning Kills One Soldier and Injures 9 Others at Georgia Army Base
description: Sgt. First Class Michael D. Clark, who survived four deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan, died from the lightning strike while training at Fort Gordon, the Army said.
content: One soldier was killed and nine others were injured in a lightning strike on Wednesday at the Fort Gordon Army base in Georgia, a spokeswoman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden has begun taking Paxlovid, an antiviral medication shown to prevent serious Covid cases.
description: Researchers are still working to answer key questions about the drug, including how effective it is in vaccinated people and whether cases of “rebounding” in people who receive it are common.
content: The antiviral pill that President Biden began taking after testing positive for the coronavirus has been shown to protect people at high risk of advancing to more serious cases of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia continues to bombard Kharkiv despite little recent progress in Moscow’s eastern campaign.
description: Even as Russian forces have stalled in their advance in eastern Ukraine, they continued their unrelenting bombardment of the country’s second largest city, Kharkiv, on Thursday as the Ukrainians in turn pursued a limited counteroffensive in the direction of the eastern city.
content: Even as Russian forces have stalled in their advance in eastern Ukraine, they continued their unrelenting bombardment of the country’s second largest city, Kharkiv, on Thursday as the Ukrainians in turn pursued a limited counteroffensive in the direction of the eastern city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Hip, Woke, Cool: It’s All Fodder For the Oxford Dictionary of African American English
description: The new lexicon, with Henry Louis Gates Jr. as editor in chief, will collect definitions and histories of words. “The bottom line of the African American people,” Gates said, is “these are people who love language.”
content: The first time she heard Barbara Walters use the expression “shout out” on television, Tracey Weldon took note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The Jan. 6 panel begins to sum up its case against Trump.
description: In a hearing aimed at putting a capstone on the public sessions thus far, two military veterans will make the case that Mr. Trump neglected his presidential duties when he refused to call off the mob.
content: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol returned to prime time on Thursday to deliver what amounts to a closing argument in the case it has made against former President Donald J. Trump, accusing the former commander in chief of dereliction of duty for failing to call off the assault carried out in his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta tweaks Facebook app to act more like TikTok.
description: An update will highlight a new Home tab that will serve content from people outside a user’s Facebook connections as well as from friends and family.
content: For most of Facebook’s history, its executives have executed a tried-and-true playbook: Mimic the success of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: I Was Wrong About Al Franken
description: Due process is important.
content: During the height of the #MeToo movement in 2017, a woman named Leeann Tweeden accused Al Franken of sexually harassing her during his comedian days and produced a photo of him pretending to grope her breasts. I called on Franken to resign from the Senate, not because I thought his alleged actions were irredeemable, but because I thought Democrats should free themselves of the burden of defending him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: I Was Wrong About Facebook
description: Yes, 13 years ago I was an evangelist for the social media platform.
content: Early in 2009, I offered the world some tech advice that I have regretted pretty much ever since: I told everyone to join Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Remy Tumin
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Welcome to Chicago, Hot Dog Town, U.S.A.
description: Just don’t even think about asking for ketchup.
content: CHICAGO — Before leaving the city for graduate school, Heidi Ratanavanich got a shoulder tattoo of a Chicago-style hot dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey C. Kummer and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Ex-Officer Who Held George Floyd’s Legs Sentenced to 30 Months in Prison
description: Thomas Lane, 39, helped to hold Mr. Floyd down while another officer fatally knelt on his neck. He was the only officer to suggest they should roll Mr. Floyd on his side so he could breathe.
content: ST. PAUL, Minn. — Thomas Lane, a former Minneapolis police officer who held down George Floyd’s legs as he gasped for air while dying under the knee of another officer, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: I Was Wrong About Mitt Romney (and His Dog)
description: Yes, he was boring. But there are some things much worse than boring.
content: I’ve been thinking about columns I’ve come to regret over the years. Hmm, lots of potential there. But let me go back to Mitt Romney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Uwe Seeler, One of Germany’s Greatest Soccer Players, Dies at 85
description: He led West Germany to the 1966 World Cup, but his teams never won a title. Pele included him on his list of the world’s premier living players.
content: Uwe Seeler, who led West Germany to the 1966 World Cup final as captain of the national team, has died. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: I Was Wrong About Why Protests Work
description: I thought that an unprecedented crowd would lead to policy change. What happened?
content: Growing up in Turkey, with my childhood under the shadow of heavy censorship, I was fascinated by what new technologies would mean for the world and especially for free speech and dissent. I got into a graduate school in the United States, hoping to study how the internet and the digital transformation were affecting society. I was especially curious about the relationships among technology, dissent and protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: There’s a Reason We Can’t Have Nice Things
description: “Racism has undermined efforts to deliver a social safety net in the U.S. for a very long time,” one scholar says.
content: The United States is one of six countries in the world without a national guarantee of paid parental leave. Twenty-three other countries have universal child or family allowances. We spend just 0.2 percent of our gross domestic product on child care for our youngest children, compared with an average of 0.7 percent among countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The Man of a Thousand Faces
description: Anne Marie Crinnion and Eric Bornstein drop in on us.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It’s very easy to get tunnel vision when you’re solving a crossword, because it can be an overwhelming task. When you’re concentrating on getting an answer right, you’re not thinking about the puzzle as a whole. I believe that’s why so many people say they sometimes solve an entire puzzle without noticing the theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flo Wales Bonner
title: In an Orchard With Blooming Poppies, an Anniversary in the Cotswolds
description: Melissa Morris, the founder of the bag and accessories line Métier, threw an intimate dinner at the home of her friend Silka Rittson-Thomas.
content: It was a perfectly crafted bag that brought together Melissa Morris, the American founder of the London-based leather house Métier, and Silka Rittson-Thomas, an art adviser and creative consultant. About four and a half years ago, Rittson-Thomas (who is also a contributing editor to T) purchased a Métier Private Eye bag — a chic, roomy style constructed from lightweight leather, with ergonomic spaces for a laptop and other essentials. She instantly adored it and, soon after, went to meet Morris in person at the brand’s store in Mayfair. They’ve been friends ever since. So, when Morris mentioned to Rittson-Thomas that the brand’s fifth anniversary was coming up, and that she wanted to throw some kind of summer celebration to mark it, Rittson-Thomas suggested she hold the event in the gardens of Walcot House, her home in the Cotswolds that she shares with her husband, the photographer Hugo Rittson-Thomas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Passes Bill to Ensure Contraception Rights After Dobbs
description: The vote was mostly along party lines, with all but eight Republicans in opposition to a bill that aims to protect a right seen as newly at risk after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday passed legislation to ensure access to contraception nationwide, moving over almost unanimous Republican opposition to protect a right that is regarded as newly under threat after the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Putin, Chekhov and the Theater of Despair
description: In London, a new play about President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and a revival of “The Seagull” explore undercurrents of pain.
content: LONDON — There’s a chill in the air at the Almeida Theater, notwithstanding the record-breaking heat here. That drop in temperature comes from the coolly unnerving “Patriots,” a new drama whose look at power politics in Russia over the last quarter-century induces a shiver at despotism’s rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Nearly a Third of Gen Z Is Living at Home (and They Plan to Stay)
description: And among those who moved out of their childhood bedroom, a third are spending about half of their monthly income on rent or mortgage.
content: This year’s rapid inflation rates have meant higher prices for virtually everything, including rent, food and even partying. So what comes next may not be much of a surprise: Nearly a third of Americans between the ages of 18 and 25 — part of what is collectively known as Gen Z — live at home with their parents or other relatives, according to a new study, and they considered it a long-term housing solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Amanda Shires Isn’t Letting Nashville, or Her Marriage, Off the Hook
description: The singer, songwriter and fiddler found comfort with an unexpected collaborator and plumbed new depths on her latest album, “Take It Like a Man.”
content: Amanda Shires wasn’t trying to name-drop, honest. It’s just that she’s been working alongside country music legends since she was 15, so most of the characters who populate her anecdotes happen to need no introduction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: Snap reports its slowest quarterly growth and a wider loss in the second quarter.
description: The company declined to forecast its future financial performance, citing “uncertainties related to the operating environment.”
content: Snap, the maker of Snapchat, on Thursday reported its slowest-ever rate of quarterly growth and a wider financial loss, while declining to predict its future performance because of “uncertainties related to the operating environment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: At Ivana Trump’s Funeral, a Gold-Hued Coffin and the Secret Service
description: “People adored Ivana.”
content: In death, as in life, her famous former husband loomed over Ivana Trump’s story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Stacey Abrams aims to put abortion at the center of the Georgia governor’s race.
description: After a court ruling put the state’s six-week abortion ban back into effect, Ms. Abrams said that while economic struggles would come and go, “this law is permanent.”
content: ATLANTA — Stacey Abrams, the Democratic nominee for governor of Georgia, is racing to turn abortion rights supporters’ frustrations and fears into electoral gains for her party after a court ruling reinstated the state’s six-week ban on the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Maggie Haberman
title: Panel Chairman Bennie Thompson to Preside Remotely After Positive Test
description: Mr. Thompson, a Mississippi Democrat, tested positive for the coronavirus this week.
content: Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the chairman of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the United States Capitol, tested positive for Covid-19 this week but plans to preside over Thursday night’s hearing remotely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Werner Reich, Who Learned Magic in Auschwitz, Dies at 94
description: He was 16 when a fellow inmate, a magician, taught him a card trick in the barracks of the extermination camp. He called it a “miracle.”
content: In the Auschwitz barracks where starving, emaciated, dying men were crammed six to a bed, Werner Reich’s closest neighbor was a gentlemanly German Jewish man in his 30s named Herbert Levin, who had been known before World War II as Nivelli the magician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson and Emily Anthes
title: Vice President Harris tests negative, and her schedule will continue as planned.
description: Ms. Harris last saw President Biden two days before he tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Although Vice President Kamala Harris was infected by the coronavirus in April, it’s not impossible that she could become infected again — a prospect raised by her being with President Biden just two days before he tested positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: Truckers’ protests over a labor law block access to Oakland’s port.
description: The truckers say they’re concerned that a law classifying many freelance workers as employees could hurt their ability to operate independently.
content: For days, a convoy of truckers has blocked the roads that serve the Port of Oakland, crippling a major West Coast cargo hub already hampered by global supply chain disruptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Shame of Uvalde
description: What happened there was a ‘systemic failure.’ But what do we mean by that?
content: This week, an investigative committee of the Texas House of Representatives released a report about what went wrong during the shooting in Uvalde. People hungry for new information might come away dissatisfied. As my colleagues J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval reported for The Times on Sunday, the committee’s report doesn’t alter the overall understanding of events that much of the public already has: The May 24 massacre at Robb Elementary School was accompanied by a law enforcement meltdown that may have prevented at least some wounded teachers and students from receiving needed medical attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: I Was Wrong About Capitalism
description: I’ve been a socialist and a free-marketeer. But history changed before my eyes.
content: I have a specific way I tend to be wrong. I fall behind. Every day the world turns and every day I try to adjust my belief system to the realities of the moment. You would think I’d be able to recognize the emerging challenges and shifting tectonics fairly quickly. As a newspaper columnist, I’m paid for one skill above others: careful observation. But sometimes I’m just slow. I suffer an intellectual lag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Belgium Ratifies Prisoner-Exchange Treaty With Iran
description: Critics say that Belgium is giving into Iranian blackmail in order to secure the release of one of its nationals in Iran and that the treaty will put more Belgians in the country in danger.
content: BRUSSELS — After two days of contentious debate, Belgium’s Parliament has approved a much-criticized treaty with Iran that would allow prisoner exchanges between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Covid’s risks are concentrated among Americans of Biden’s age.
description: As of early June, four times as many Americans aged 75 to 84 were dying each week from the virus compared with people two decades younger.
content: President Biden is 79, and Americans his age and older have made up larger and larger shares of those dying from Covid in recent months. The virus has taken advantage of falling immunity caused by the time elapsed since many older people’s last vaccinations, and the Omicron variant has evolved a growing ability to skirt the body’s defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Latest Covid Surge
description: We look at what it means for the country.
content: The Covid virus has a Darwinian quality. As variants emerge, they compete with one another to become dominant. The most contagious variants tend to win the competition because they can spread more quickly. It’s survival of the fittest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Russia Restarts Gas Shipments Through Pipeline, but Keeps Germany Guessing
description: Russia is again sending natural gas through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany, but nobody knows how much and how long the fuel will flow.
content: Russia’s decision to restart the flow of natural gas through a vital pipeline on Thursday brought a moment of relief to Germany, which uses the fuel to power its most important industries and heat half its homes. But it is unlikely to be much more than that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The E.C.B. has a new tool to keep bond markets in check. It doesn’t want to use it.
description: Rapidly rising borrowing costs for Italy in recent months intensified focus on so-called market fragmentation.
content: As well as announcing its first interest rate increase in 11 years, the European Central Bank introduced a new policy tool on Thursday to limit the divergence in borrowing costs across the eurozone’s 19 members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: New Reading Curriculum Is Mired in Debate Over Race and Gender
description: Lucy Calkins’s curriculum was meant to bring phonics to struggling students. But its publication has been stalled after a debate over whether to accommodate conservative state laws.
content: Lucy Calkins, a professor at Columbia University, has long been a controversial figure in the education world for her approach to teaching reading. Her eagerly anticipated new curriculum was meant to address her critics with a more research-backed, phonics-based approach to literacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘My Old School’ Review: An Impostor Makes the Honor Roll
description: A documentary uses animation and professional actors to tell the story of a once-notorious hoax.
content: “What is a person?” It’s a profound and complicated philosophical question, posed by a man named Stefen during an interview in “My Old School.” Like most of the other people who appear on camera in this brisk, slippery documentary, Stefen has a particular person in mind, a student at Bearsden Academy in the early ’90s known to his classmates as Brandon Lee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Alone Together’ Review: Finding Love in a Pandemic Retreat
description: Katie Holmes writes, directs and stars in this minor-key rom-com set in 2020.
content: The minor key romance “Alone Together” is a modest affair, which credibly depicts the kinds of conversations about relationships that many people were confronted with during the early days of the pandemic. Its simplicity and lack of cinematic fancy strikes a tone of surprising relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Decision Day for the E.C.B.
description: And a SoftBank-backed start up that wants to save your 401(k).
content: The European Central Bank increased its benchmark interest rates today for the first time in a decade, as inflation surges across countries that use the euro. The bank’s benchmark interest rates, before the increase, had been a negative 0.5 percent. Europe’s central bank raised those rates today by half of a percentage point or back to zero. It first set the rate below zero, an unusual move for a central bank, in 2014, and has kept it in negative territory since.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bar-Hopping Tour of New York’s Downtown Natural Wine Spots
description: Plus: a luxury home rental in Provence, reef-safe sunscreens and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 13 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Reading picks from our staff critics and Book Review editors.
content: Intellectual pursuits, criminal pursuits, fleshly pursuits: The thrill of the chase runs through this week’s recommended titles, from John Walsh’s “Circus of Dreams,” about literary London in the 1980s, to Frank Close’s “Elusive,” about the physicist Peter Higgs and his search for a subatomic particle, to Lina Wolff’s novel “Carnality,” in which the intellectual and the criminal and the fleshly get together for a raucous free-for-all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steph Cha
title: A Quicksilver Mystery That Flickers, Flashes, Twists and Turns
description: Riku Onda’s “Fish Swimming in Dappled Sunlight,” set over a single night, explores the role a couple may have played in the death of their hiking guide.
content: Riku Onda has been a fixture of Japanese suspense literature since the 1990s, but she found her audience in the Anglophone world with her 2020 English-language debut, “The Aosawa Murders,” translated by Alison Watts and released by Bitter Lemon Press, a small London-based publisher of international crime fiction. “Fish Swimming in Dappled Sunlight,” a dreamy, circuitous psychological thriller, is Onda’s second work to be translated into English, again by Watts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Teare and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Excerpts from the Poem ‘Headlands Quadrats’
description: A masterwork in opposites.
content: These excerpts are a masterwork in opposites — shape and disarray, the known and the unknown, desert and blooming, doom and hope. The small sections physically look like plots used for ecological studies, their insides brimming with language, emotion and movement. Language occasionally cuts with slanted syntax. A doe’s fear is described so that the reader can feel this fear through discombobulated language. There’s more subtle surprise, too, with the gentle synesthesia of “a coyote/exactly the color of July.” The repetition of war and complicity is deftly handled: “the ridge we curl into/during a different war//without trees to shade/their names soldiers did too.”  Poem Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: The Hole in the Center of American Politics
description: Disaffected Republicans have taken wildly divergent paths to opposing Donald Trump. We will soon get new tests of whose strategy is working better.
content: Republican politicians who don’t support Donald Trump have made starkly different choices over the last five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Boyfriend’s Ex Moved Across the Street From Us. Again. Should We Move?
description: A reader wonders what to do about a partner’s ex-wife who lives too close for comfort.
content: Several years ago, while my boyfriend was out of the country, his then wife withdrew half their savings from the bank and moved to another state in secret. They divorced, and we met. Last year, his ex-wife decided to move back to our small city and bought a condo across the street from my boyfriend’s house. She changed her mind, though, and sold it quickly. Last month, she bought another house on the street a bit farther away. (Sigh!) She also initiates contact with my boyfriend. He and I had decided that I was going to move in with him this fall, but should we choose another neighborhood instead?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Abbot, Peter Chiarelli, John Jumper, James Loy, John Nathman, William Owens and Johnnie Wilson
title: We Are Retired Generals and Admirals. Trump’s Actions on Jan. 6 Were a Dereliction of Duty.
description: A civilian leader’s misuse of the military could imperil one of the foundations of American democracy.
content: The inquiry by the House’s Jan. 6 committee has produced many startling findings, but none to us more alarming than the fact that while rioters tried to thwart the peaceful transfer of power and ransacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the president and commander in chief, Donald Trump, abdicated his duty to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Mattel reports a 20 percent jump in sales.
description: Revenue for the second quarter was $1.2 billion, up from $1 billion in the same quarter last year, which helped the toymaker swing to a profit of $66.4 million.
content: Mattel said on Thursday that its revenue jumped 20 percent in the second quarter despite rising prices, a sign that consumers were continuing to buy Polly Pocket dolls and Mega construction sets despite rising inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Getting more Covid aid passed has stalled in Congress after lawmakers have fought about spending and how to pay for it.
description: It remains unclear whether lawmakers will reach agreement on another round of coronavirus aid, even as President Biden tests positive for the virus.
content: President Biden’s Covid diagnosis on Thursday comes as his request to Congress to approve billions of dollars in additional pandemic aid remains stalled, with lawmakers unable to agree over how much to spend and how to pay for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: A Recession Alarm Is Ringing on Wall Street
description: An inversion of the bond market’s yield curve has preceded every U.S. recession for the past half century. It is happening again.
content: Wall Street’s most-talked-about recession indicator is sounding its loudest alarm in two decades, intensifying concerns among investors that the U.S. economy is heading toward a slowdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Yuvraj Khanna
title: Through It All, Staten Island Cricket Endures
description: The club, which has been in continuous operation since before the invention of airplanes and the game of basketball, recently celebrated its 150th anniversary.
content: The moment that Nancy Johnson saw the gentlemen in white throwing and batting on the thin, sandy pitch carved into Walker Park on Saturday, she flashed back to the 1950s. As a young girl, she had gone with her father, who was from Grenada, to the same park on Staten Island, sometimes with a picnic basket, and watched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: A Painful Deadline Nears as Colorado River Reservoirs Run Critically Low
description: The federal government has told states to agree on urgent water cuts to ensure dams can keep generating power. Researchers say reductions once considered “unthinkable” may be necessary in the long term.
content: States in the Colorado River basin are scrambling to propose steep cuts in the water they’ll use from the river next year, in response to a call by the federal government for immediate, drastic efforts to keep the river’s main storage reservoirs from reaching critically low levels.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Seeking ‘Axis of Good’ Against U.S., Russia Taps Allies of Convenience
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 21, 2022.
content: “No one really likes China, but everyone understands their power. Russia is worse — they have the soft power of a drunken porcupine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: What Would a Climate Emergency Mean? Here Are 4 Key Points.
description: As 100 million Americans swelter under heat warnings, the president is considering whether to invoke special powers to address climate change.
content: President Biden faces growing calls from members of his own party to declare climate change a national emergency, which would unlock certain temporary powers to bolster renewable energy and curb investments in fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: American Airlines has its best quarter of revenue ever, but profit is down from 2019.
description: Like other carriers, American benefited from a travel rebound, but higher costs took a toll on its bottom line.
content: American Airlines reported $13.4 billion in revenue in the three months that ended in June, the best quarter in the company’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Still Doesn’t See Any Good Arguments Against Gay Marriage
description: “The House has officially passed a bill legalizing gay and interracial marriage, which is a great victory for 1995,” Noah joked on Wednesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Central Park’s Boathouse Restaurant to Shut Down
description: The Boathouse first saw life as a Victorian structure in the 1870s, and will see the end of its latest chapter come October. A new operator is in the works.
content: The Loeb Boathouse in Central Park, an iconic restaurant and venue that has appeared in a number of film classics and has drawn New York tourists and high society alike for decades, will shut its doors on Oct. 16.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Ukraine Launches a Southern Counteroffensive
description: Also, President Biden tests positive for Covid and Europe’s central bank raises its rates.
content: Ukrainian officials said their forces used long-range missiles and artillery to attack more than 200 Russian targets in the south on Thursday. The strikes destroyed six ammunition depots, the military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Republicans Are Having Gas Pains
description: Their focus on gas prices is profoundly stupid. If it’s coming back to bite themparty, that’s just poetic justice.
content: Until just the other day, Republicans and conservative media loved, just loved talking about the price of gasoline. Indeed, “Remember how cheap gas used to be under Trump?” became a sort of all-purpose answer to everything. Is there now overwhelming evidence that the former president conspired in a violent attempt to overthrow the 2020 election? “Real America doesn’t care about the January 6th Committee. Gas is over $5 a gallon!” declared Representative Jim Jordan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russ Roberts
title: How to Make a Decision When There’s No ‘Right’ One
description: Life’s biggest problems are hard to tame with rationality.
content: In 1838, Charles Darwin faced a problem. Nearing his 30th birthday, he was trying to decide whether to marry — with the likelihood that children would be part of the package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Michelle Obama Will Publish a New Book This Fall
description: In “The Light We Carry,” the former first lady will share her approaches to dealing with challenging times. Her 2018 memoir, “Becoming,” was one of the best-selling books of all time.
content: Michelle Obama’s 2018 memoir, “Becoming,” was one of the best-selling books of all time, with more than 17 million copies sold worldwide. Now she has a new book coming out this fall, Penguin Random House announced Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: I Was Wrong About Inflation
description: Some economists warned that the American Rescue Plan would be inflationary. Others, like me, were fairly relaxed.
content: In early 2021 there was an intense debate among economists about the likely consequences of the American Rescue Plan, the $1.9 trillion package enacted by a new Democratic president and a (barely) Democratic Congress. Some warned that the package would be dangerously inflationary; others were fairly relaxed. I was Team Relaxed. As it turned out, of course, that was a very bad call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 2 Are Indicted in Human Smuggling Case That Left 53 Dead in Texas
description: Two men from Texas could face the death penalty after a tractor-trailer carrying dead migrants was found on the outskirts of San Antonio last month.
content: A federal grand jury indicted two men on Wednesday in connection with a human smuggling operation that left 50 adults and three children dead in and around an abandoned tractor-trailer on the outskirts of San Antonio last month, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: I Was Wrong About Trump Voters
description: They weren’t appalling. They were angry for a reason.
content: The worst line I ever wrote as a pundit — yes, I know, it’s a crowded field — was the first line I ever wrote about the man who would become the 45th president: “If by now you don’t find Donald Trump appalling, you’re appalling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘The Reverend’ Review: A Beer With a Music Chaser
description: Get out of his way. With two decades of sharing worship and making music at a Brooklyn bar, the Rev. Vince Anderson appears to be unstoppable.
content: When singing “Get Out of My Way,” the Rev. Vince Anderson takes no time getting to a growl and a wail. Anderson, the subject of the oft-rousing documentary “The Reverend,” and his band, the Love Choir, have had a 20-year residency at Union Pool, a bar in Williamsburg. And that brassy, organ-banging, sax-honking representative of what Anderson dubs “dirty gospel’’ has been the invocation to Monday evening gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: To Illuminate History, an Artist Turns Out the Lights
description: At the New Museum, Kapwani Kiwanga explores light as a form of surveillance, from 18th-century “lantern laws” to the N.Y.P.D.’s 21st-century strategies.
content: When you first alight on the fourth floor of the New Museum, where the Canadian-born, Paris-based artist Kapwani Kiwanga has her first solo museum exhibition in New York, it may take you a second to realize what’s different. But start to walk around the soaring gallery of “Off-Grid” and it will dawn on you: there is no familiar electrical brightness here, only whatever light streams through distant windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Russia resumes gas flow through key pipeline to Germany.
description: Gas began flowing early Thursday through a pipeline that normally provides more than a third of Germany’s needs as well as essential gas supplies to several of its European partners.
content: Gas began flowing early Thursday through a pipeline that normally provides more than a third of Germany’s needs as well as essential gas supplies to several of its European partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Biden had received a second booster. Here’s why it wasn’t enough to prevent infection.
description: The Omicron variant is evolving in ways that make it better able to evade the body’s immune defenses. But booster shots still help prevent severe illness.
content: President Biden’s coronavirus infection is a stark illustration that the Covid vaccines, powerful as they are, are far from the bulletproof shields that scientists once hoped for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘First Person'
title: A Pastor Ripped Apart by Our Divided Country
description: For Dan White Jr., a trauma diagnosis pushed him toward a new calling: helping other exhausted faith leaders find peace.
content: America is burned out. Between the stress of the pandemic, growing polarization and declining trust in institutions, many people are near their breaking point. The feeling is particularly acute for those who have traditionally been society’s bridge builders — teachers, health care workers, faith leaders — as they increasingly find themselves in the cross hairs of our divisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Art of Love’ Review: An Erotic Male Fantasy in Puerto Rico
description: A disillusioned college professor develops a relationship with a young Chinese woman, in a familiar and worn-out narrative.
content: You know the story: A disenchanted writer and college professor is seduced by a younger woman, snapping him out of an existential lull and helping him reconnect with his creativity. It’s a narrative that lands clumsily in 2022, romanticizing a problematic power dynamic and casting women as mere accessories to a man’s personal growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beejay Silcox
title: Murder in the Brain-Broiling Heat and Red Dust of the Outback
description: Two new novels, “Dirt Creek” and “Wake,” are set in remote towns hours from anywhere and on the road to nowhere.
content: Imagine a remote Australian town, hours from anywhere and on the road to nowhere. Bypassed by highways, forgotten by time. There are no tourist-bait boutiques — no farmers’ markets or dinky little tearooms — just a handful of relics: a dingy pub, a school, a half-stocked grocery store, a one-man cop shop. A church or two. Imagine a town of rough-handed men and stoic women; of cast-iron silences and failing farms; of swift gossip and slow reckonings. A town baked to dust by the paint-stripping, brain-boiling Aussie heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: Newman and Woodward, Mr. and Mrs. Movie Star
description: Ethan Hawke’s HBO Max documentary “The Last Movie Stars” examines two great actors in their own, and many of their friends’, words.
content: Ethan Hawke begins “The Last Movie Stars,” his six-hour documentary about Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, with a video-conferenced gathering. Peering into a laptop, his pandemic hair curling over his shoulders, he welcomes a similarly informal procession of actors to his project: George Clooney, Laura Linney, Billy Crudup, Oscar Isaac, Zoe Kazan, Sally Field, Sam Rockwell and many others. It’s like watching a cast gather for an early-morning table read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: When ‘New Art’ Made New York the Culture Capital
description: Artists in the early 1960s drew from a heady mix: Mad magazine and Marilyn; the civil rights movement and the death of a president; queer bodies and “Pieta.” It’s all at the Jewish Museum.
content: When I was a kid in the early 1960s, my Eisenhower-Republican physician-father always had the latest copies of his favored subscription publications on his home office desk: Time, Life, the Journal of the American Medical Association, and Mad magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Secret Platform That Might Make Penn Station Better
description: State officials are expected to approve Gov. Kathy Hochul’s plan for supertall towers near Penn. But is there another way to improve the station?
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Scroll down to find out where masks are still required in New York — and where they probably won’t be required, come September. But first, a look at what I’d been told was a secret place in Pennsylvania Station that could be repurposed to make life easier for commuters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: How to Get Vaccinated, Tested and Treated for Monkeypox
description: A guide to finding the medical care you may need during the current outbreak.
content: As a monkeypox outbreak continues to swell across the United States, health experts have said that expanded testing, vaccination and treatment will be important for curbing the disease. But these critical tools are still not widely available, and it can be difficult to try to get a diagnosis and find access to medication that may help your symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Gibbs
title: President Biden Has Covid. Now What?
description: “If all goes well, this will be a nonstory … and that’s the story.”
content: The president has tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima
title: A Village Retaken, and a Confidence Boost for Ukraine’s Troops
description: A Ukrainian brigade surprised Russian forces to score a rare success in the east and send a signal to other units that the Russians can be routed in this region, too.
content: PAVLIVKA, Ukraine — A sheepdog, padding the streets on his own, was the only sign of life in this destroyed village. Flames licked the rafters of the school and smoke poured out of a burning house several streets away after Russian artillery strikes earlier in the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: Counting the Detained in Egypt
description: A Times investigation peeked behind the veil hiding political prisoners in a special court in Cairo.
content: In November 2020, Vivian Yee, the Cairo bureau chief for The New York Times, was in the Egyptian city to cover a prosecutorial hearing of Gasser Abdel-Razek, an advocate for human rights. The government had accused Mr. Abdel-Razek, along with two others, of working for a terrorist organization and spreading false information. Such accusations were increasingly used against critics and political opponents of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who came to power after a military coup in 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
title: The C.I.A. director says Putin believes the U.S. will forget about Ukraine.
description: The C.I.A. director says that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia believes that America will suffer from “attention deficit disorder” and lose interest and resolve in the Ukraine war.
content: The C.I.A. director says that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia believes that America will suffer from “attention deficit disorder” and lose interest and resolve in the Ukraine war.

title: Overlooked No More: Lottie Brunn, the ‘Queen of Jugglers’
description: Known as the world’s fastest woman juggler, she assisted her brother before launching a three-decade solo career.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy’s President Accepts Draghi Resignation, Calling for New Elections
description: Italy now ends a period of relative stability and influence and faces the prospect of a chaotic campaign that a right-wing alliance is best positioned to win.
content: ROME — Italy’s president on Thursday accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Mario Draghi, dissolved Parliament and called for new elections, bringing to a close an exceptional period of Italian stability and influence, and opening what promised to be a chaotic political season as Europe struggles to maintain resolve in the face of Russian aggression.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Weapons, New Confidence
description: Ukraine is pointing to battlefield successes to make the case that it can beat Russia.

author: By Alan Scherstuhl
title: Smoke Rises: A Jazz Room Returns on the Upper West Side
description: This storefront club that’s been mostly shuttered since spring 2020 has long been home to small-group jazz steeped in tradition. Now, it reopens, with some renovations.
content: On a recent Friday evening at Smoke, the storefront Upper West Side jazz club that’s been mostly shuttered since the spring of 2020, owners and staff scrambled about as you might expect in the run-up to a long-awaited reopening. As the crowd took its seats for a preview concert, technicians climbed ladders and handled minor crises. One of the venue’s co-owners, Paul Stache, consulted with an engineer on the in-room and livestream sound, while the other, Molly Sparrow Johnson, kept tabs on a wait staff that will be serving an expanded capacity of about 80 when it reopens on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Miami-Dade School Board Rejects New Textbooks With Sex Education Curriculum
description: The school board had voted in April to approve the textbooks but reversed its decision after it was met with petitions from parents citing what opponents call Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” law.
content: Facing pressure from parents empowered by a new state education law, the Miami-Dade County School Board has reversed itself on adopting two new textbooks for the coming school year, leaving students without a sexual education curriculum for the next several months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Search for Hoffa Under Jersey City Bridge Came Up Empty, F.B.I. Says
description: The 1975 disappearance of the Teamsters leader has long been the subject of rumors and intrigue.
content: It appeared to be a promising lead into the location of the remains of Jimmy Hoffa, the boss of the Teamsters union who disappeared 47 years ago: the deathbed account of a man who claimed to have buried the body in a barrel with an excavator in Jersey City, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ronni Solbert, Children’s Book Illustrator, Dies at 96
description: She did the artwork for dozens of books, notably “The Pushcart War,” a parable about overcoming bullies, written by her partner, Jean Merrill.
content: In 1961, Ronni Solbert was living with her partner, Jean Merrill, on the north side of Tompkins Square Park, in Manhattan’s East Village, alongside the immigrants and bohemians who defined the neighborhood’s idyllic, small-town-in-a-big-city vibe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Noah Lyles Is Ready for His Moment This Time
description: At heart, Noah Lyles is a performer. A performer who needs an audience. His 200-meter showdown with Erriyon Knighton will deliver one.
content: Noah Lyles danced across the red track at Hayward Field. He slapped hands and mugged for selfies with the fans and smiled as though he had won another world championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Jonas Vingegaard All but Clinches Tour de France With Win in Pyrenees
description: A Danish rider looking to defend his lead instead widens it, effectively finishing off his biggest rival with only days to go.
content: Tadej Pogacar’s last chance to position himself to win his third straight Tour de France arrived Thursday on the steep slopes of the Hautacam in the Pyrenees Mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and John Liu
title: China Fines Didi $1.2 Billion as Tech Sector Pressures Persist
description: Regulators sought to make the company an example of the consequences of mishandling data — and of the grave political error of ignoring the authorities.
content: In slapping China’s ride-hailing giant, Didi Global, with a record $1.2 billion fine for data breaches, Beijing made clear to the country’s internet companies that their freewheeling days were over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The Jan. 6 committee isn’t even close to being finished.
description: The panel once planned to hold all its public hearings in June and issue a final report by September. Now, more hearings are possible and findings probably won’t be complete until December.
content: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol doesn’t plan to conclude its work any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Is Life a Story or a Game?
description: Modern culture has a dehumanizing way of seeing the world.
content: I’m a liberal arts type, so I see life as a story. Each person is born into a family. Over the course of life, we find things to love and commit to — a vocation, a spouse, a community. At times, we flounder and suffer but do our best to learn from our misfortunes to grow in wisdom, kindness and grace. At the end, hopefully, we can look back and see how we have nurtured deep relationships and served a higher good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Ex-Coinbase Employee and 2 Others Charged With Insider Trading of Crypto Assets
description: The case is the first time criminal insider-trading charges have been filed that involve cryptocurrency assets, a U.S. attorney said.
content: Federal authorities filed criminal and civil charges against a former Coinbase employee and two other men in an insider trading case involving confidential information about cryptocurrency assets that were about to be posted on Coinbase’s exchange, according to charging documents filed on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: She Wants to Heal the World Through Second Line
description: Michelle N. Gibson brings her one-woman show exploring the origins of New Orleans second line, “Takin’ It to the Roots,” to Jacob’s Pillow.
content: In most places, people either watch parades or march in them. In New Orleans, they have another option: second line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Trees Dedicated to Holocaust Victims Are Destroyed at Buchenwald
description: Seven trees near the former concentration camp in Germany were chopped down in what the International Committee of Buchenwald Dora said was a “horrible act of vandalism.”
content: Seven trees memorializing people who died at Buchenwald during the Holocaust were chopped down on Tuesday near the former concentration camp outside Weimar, Germany, in what the International Committee of Buchenwald Dora called a “horrible act of vandalism.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Train Fire Outside Boston Prompts Evacuation, and a Leap Into the Mystic River
description: The authorities said that no one was injured in the fire, which they said started after a metal strip came loose from the train and made contact with the third rail.
content: A subway train outside Boston caught fire on Thursday morning as it crossed a bridge over the Mystic River, prompting an evacuation that led many to climb out of windows and one person to leap into the water below, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Tests Positive for Virus and Is Experiencing Mild Symptoms
description: The president tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday and is expected to isolate for at least five days before resuming normal activities.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden tested positive on Thursday for the coronavirus, raising health concerns for the 79-year-old president and underscoring how the virus remains a persistent, if muted, threat in a country trying to put the pandemic in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maham Javaid
title: Putin is ‘entirely too healthy,’ the C.I.A. director says.
description: There is no evidence that the Russian president is unwell, Western intelligence officials said, after the Kremlin denied rumors about his health.
content: Western intelligence officials, as well as the Kremlin, this week dismissed longstanding rumors that Vladimir V. Putin, the 69-year-old Russian president, is unwell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: He Built a Home to Survive a Civil War. Tragedy Found Him Anyway.
description: C. Wesley Morgan once believed that the place he built, which included a 2,000-square-foot bunker, was the safest house in Kentucky.
content: RICHMOND, Ky. — The doorbell rang in the night, waking C. Wesley Morgan. He rolled out of bed and walked into the foyer, looking through the arched glass entryway into the dark. Nobody. These phantom rings had been happening lately; most likely there was a short somewhere in the system. The rain didn’t help. He went back to bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Do Californians Want Mask Mandates to Come Back?
description: Readers tell us.
content: As you’re probably well aware, the latest Covid surge has reignited a debate about mandatory masking in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Magnus Carlsen Is Giving Up His World Title. Replacing Him Won’t Be Easy.
description: The decision by the world’s best player to surrender his title means the game will have a new champion. But taking the crown is not the same as beating the man.
content: The decision announced Wednesday by Magnus Carlsen, the reigning world chess champion, to skip the chance to defend the crown in a match next year means that there will soon be a new titleholder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The risk from the coronavirus is rising in much of the United States.
description: Still, many Americans have turned their attention away from the pandemic, and many health officials have grown more hesitant to sound the alarm.
content: In just eight weeks, the Omicron subvariant known as BA.5 has gone from a blip in United States case counts to the dominant version of the coronavirus in the country, now making up more than three-quarters of new cases. Perhaps the most transmissible subvariant yet, BA.5 is driving increases in positive tests, hospitalizations and intensive care admissions across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: First Polio Case in Nearly a Decade Is Detected in New York State
description: A man who lives in Rockland County was infected by someone who received the oral polio vaccine, which is no longer used in the United States, officials said.
content: A case of polio has been identified in an unvaccinated adult man in Rockland County, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine Tries to Make the Case That It Can Win, Citing Recent Strikes
description: Pushing back against skepticism that Western weapons will allow them to turn the tide against Russia, Ukrainians point to successful attacks using new long-range rocket systems.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Just weeks ago, Ukraine’s military was being pummeled relentlessly in the East, taking heavy casualties as it slowly gave ground to the Russian advance. Western support appeared to be softening, amid skepticism that Ukraine could win a war of attrition, or that an influx of sophisticated weapons would turn the tide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Black Leaders Are Conveying the Far Left’s Unease With Eric Adams
description: Unlike some of their white peers, activists of color have pushed back sharply against the mayor’s aggressive approach to battling crime in New York City.
content: Outside City Hall, as a nonprofit social justice group was unveiling a report about public safety for Black New Yorkers, Mayor Eric Adams suddenly emerged from the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ari Saperstein
title: ‘Best Foot Forward’ Is a Story About, and By, People With Disabilities
description: The Apple TV+ series, based loosely on a memoir by Josh Sundquist, prioritized disability representation on both sides of the camera.
content: Casting the right actor for a role often means finding someone who matches the character description in a script, but Josh Sundquist didn’t know if that was possible for his series “Best Foot Forward.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: BBC Apologizes to Royal Nanny Swept Up in Diana Reporting Furor
description: Suggestions that a nanny for the children of Princess Diana and Prince Charles was involved with the prince were “wholly baseless,” the British broadcaster said as it agreed to pay her damages.
content: LONDON — She was collateral damage in one of the most sensational reporting scoops in British TV history, a royal nanny to Prince William and Prince Harry tarnished by the BBC in its quest for an interview with their mother, Princess Diana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan and Thomas Prior
title: Wait, La Guardia Is Nice Now? Inside New York’s $25 Billion Airport Overhaul
description: The city is not exactly known for its state-of-the-art airports. That should change by 2030.
content: Complaining about the sorry state of New York City’s airports has become a national pastime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Wheel’ Review: Songs of Love and Hate
description: In this marriage drama, a young couple heads to the countryside to break out of a toxic cycle.
content: Not many movies faithfully recreate just how awful (and interminable) some arguments between couples can feel, but “The Wheel” boldly makes the effort. In fact, the young couple at the film’s raw center — married in their teens, locked into toxic dysfunction in their 20s — could probably have been pulled out of their car wreck of a marriage long ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Covid precautions around Biden have varied over his time in office.
description: At the start of Mr. Biden’s term, the White House went to great lengths to avoid infection and did most business virtually. But face-to-face contacts have grown more common over time.
content: President Biden’s aides took extraordinary measures when he first came into the Oval Office to try to protect the president from the virus, in a marked contrast from the Trump White House.

author: By Steve Lohr
title: How Software Is Stifling Competition and Slowing Innovation

content: More than a decade ago, Marc Andreessen, the internet entrepreneur and venture capitalist, famously declared, “Software is eating the world.”

author: By Jack Ewing and Karen Weise
title: Amazon Wants 100,000 Electric Vans. Can Rivian Deliver?
description: Amazon has ordered 100,000 trucks to cut its carbon dioxide emissions, but Rivian will take years to deliver.
content: Nearly three years ago, Amazon announced that it would buy 100,000 custom-made delivery vehicles from Rivian, a fledgling maker of electric vehicles. On Thursday, after some delays, the companies said hundreds of the vans were finally on the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: 20 Wines Under $20: Great Summer Values
description: The selection in stores is a little thin as the global economy has slowed, but plenty of great seasonal bottles are still available.
content: In the stores where I shop for wine, the shelves have looked a bit less packed than usual with intriguing bottles. I suspect I’m not the only one to notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Fox News Will Not Carry Thursday’s Jan. 6 Hearing Live
description: The network will keep its usual prime-time lineup instead. Its sister network, Fox Business, will air the hearing.
content: The wall-to-wall cable news and network coverage of Thursday’s prime-time Jan. 6 committee hearing will once again have a notable gap: Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Marc Santora
title: Russia restarts gas shipments through a key pipeline to Germany.
description: The suspense was another reminder of the reliance of Germany, and much of the rest of Europe, on Russian energy. European Union leaders urged members to cut natural gas use immediately.
content: BERLIN — Russia resumed flows of natural gas to Germany early Thursday, easing fears in Europe that a key pipeline would become the latest target in the escalating confrontation between Moscow and the West as the war in Ukraine stretches into its fifth month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Brunch Parameters
description: Two friends can’t agree on when the meal begins and ends.
content: Andy writes: My friend and I have debated the concept of brunch for years. He eats “brunch” in the afternoon. He can eat when he wants, but words have meanings. And brunch is a meal between breakfast and lunch that takes place before noon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘My Donkey, My Lover & I’ Review: Three’s a Crowd
description: In this idiosyncratic comedy from France, a besotted schoolteacher crashes her married lover’s hiking trip and befriends a deeply opinionated donkey.
content: “My Donkey, My Lover & I” is yet another story about a woman who ventures out into the wild and finds herself. But to the writer and director Caroline Vignal’s credit, this low-key romantic French comedy proves friskier and more idiosyncratic than its reliance on this trope of feminist empowerment would suggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Maggie Haberman
title: A Jan. 6 Mystery: Why Did It Take So Long to Deploy the National Guard?
description: The House committee’s hearing on Thursday shed light on the Trump White House’s inaction as others urged to send troops to help quell the violence at the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — As the House committee investigating Jan. 6 used its prime-time hearing on Thursday to document President Donald J. Trump’s lack of forceful response to the attack on the Capitol by his supporters, it again raised one of the enduring mysteries of that day: Why did it take so long to deploy the National Guard?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Europe Joins Fight Against Inflation, Raising Rates for First Time in 11 Years
description: Policymakers are trying to slow soaring prices while avoiding a recession among the countries that use the euro.
content: FRANKFURT — As consumer prices across Europe soar at the fastest rate in generations, officials in Frankfurt on Thursday took a powerful step to control rapid inflation amid mounting concerns over an economic slowdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon to acquire One Medical clinics in latest push into health care.
description: The $3.9 billion deal is Amazon’s latest acquisition in the health care industry. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.
content: SEATTLE — Just two months ago, Andy Jassy, almost a year into his reign as Amazon’s chief executive, told investors that driving down costs was a “really big area of focus,” after the company produced its worst quarterly earnings in years. But that didn’t mean he wasn’t open to a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland
title: The Biden administration is elevating a division of H.H.S. to more broadly oversee pandemic responses.
description: The move effectively creates a new federal agency — on par with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration.
content: The Biden administration is creating a new division within the Department of Health and Human Services to coordinate the nation’s response to pandemic threats and other health emergencies, a recognition that the department is structurally ill equipped to handle disasters like the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Events went very differently when Trump got Covid in 2020.
description: Mr. Trump’s infection, which came before vaccines were available, was kept secret for days, until he became severely ill and had to be hospitalized.
content: President Biden’s Covid diagnosis on Thursday — and what his doctor described as mild symptoms — underscored the significant progress that has been made in fighting the coronavirus in the 21 months since his predecessor was infected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ruth Ware Won’t Read ‘Bleak House’ Until She Retires
description: “There’s a temptation to rush through the canon as young as possible,” says the thriller writer, whose new novel is “The It Girl,” “but you can only ever read a book for the first time once, and I like the idea of having that to look forward to.”
content: Too many to list. I mean, literally about 20 or 30 titles. Some are old favorites that I like to dip back into after a hard day — “Howl’s Moving Castle,” by Diana Wynne Jones, would fall into that category. Some are books I finished a while ago and just haven’t moved to the shelves in my office — Sarah Pinborough’s “Insomnia” or Dorothy Koomson’s “The Ice Cream Girls,” for example. Some are books I’m in the middle of or have yet to get to — Lisa Jewell’s “The Family Remains” is one of those. I’m halfway through and got distracted by something I had to read for an event, but it’s waiting for me!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Eggplant Five Ways
description: Gain confidence cooking this summer icon with these essential techniques.
content: “No other vegetable is so content to abandon itself to your will,” Ruth Reichl wrote of eggplant in her 2015 cookbook, “My Kitchen Year.” Though if you’re skeptical, here’s one way to quickly gain some confidence: Start with her simple eggplant salad, which I’ve made so many times since first reading about it I’ve lost track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Patrick McGeehan
title: The Penn Station $7 Billion Fix-Up Moves Ahead: Here’s What to Know
description: The project promises to update the notorious eyesore but critics of the plan are concerned about the cost.
content: New York State officials on Thursday approved a sweeping redevelopment of Midtown Manhattan that would transform Pennsylvania Station, the busiest transportation hub in North America, from a run-down transit center into a city centerpiece. The eight-member board of Empire State Development, the state’s economic development agency and the group steering the project, unanimously voted in favor. The plan calls for constructing 10 towers around Penn Station and providing an estimated $1.2 billion in tax breaks to developers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Isabel Kershner
title: Russia Moves to Close Agency Handling Emigration to Israel
description: For years, Vladimir Putin worked to rebuild ties to Russia’s Jews, but the new move against a Jewish nonprofit has raised questions.
content: Russia is threatening to ban a major Jewish nonprofit agency that helps people emigrate to Israel from operating in the country, a sign of the Kremlin’s deteriorating relationship with Israel and of the far-reaching fallout from the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Deep in a Covid Wave, Europe Counts Cases and Carries On
description: Even in countries that once took strict measures, the authorities are relying on vaccination and past infections to take the sting out of Omicron subvariants.
content: ROME — Customers in the Rome bookstore paid no attention to the circular stickers on the floor instructing them to stamp out Covid by maintaining “a distance of at least 1 meter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Police Officer Dies After Medical Emergency in Louisiana Heat
description: Officer Brian Olliff called an ambulance for himself and died at the hospital, his department in Natchitoches, La., said.
content: A Louisiana police officer working outdoors in the blistering heat radioed for an ambulance to take him to the hospital over the weekend and later died from what his department called a “heat-related medical emergency.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nolan Ryan Had a Softer Side. He Just Hid It (Very) Well.
description: A new documentary explores the unique challenge of facing Ryan, the game’s most prolific strikeout artist, but also shows off a gentler version of the Ryan Express.
content: Like the Beatles did shortly before him, Nolan Ryan performed at Shea Stadium and sang on the Ed Sullivan Show.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Australia avoids reimposing restrictions as hospitalizations surge.
description: Early in the pandemic, the country had some of the world’s strictest rules, but a new government is reluctant to bring them back.
content: With coronavirus cases surging, the authorities in Australia, which imposed some of the strictest Covid rules in the world in the early stages of the pandemic, are so far refraining from bringing back restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: You Can Be Both Dull and Innovative
description: Take roof trusses.
content: Many of us are intrigued by wonders that scream “THE FUTURE” like flying cars. But sometimes the best inventions are more about brain power than technology magic. Let me give you a couple of examples in my quest to appreciate the ingenuity in boring things.

title: Lawmakers who traveled with Biden are still at the Capitol but are testing and masking.
description: Any absences as a result of positive tests, particularly in the Democratic caucuses, could delay votes on Mr. Biden’s agenda.
content: President Biden’s positive coronavirus test on Thursday offered a stark reminder of how the pandemic and the increasing number of variants continue to impede efforts to return to a normal routine in Washington.

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Skies of Lebanon’ Review: A Beautiful Life, for a While
description: A woman’s journey to Beirut leads to a storybook romance in the debut feature from the director Chloé Mazlo.
content: In the popular imagination of the West, Lebanon is most frequently invoked as a place of ruin and strife, not romance and enchantment. The debut feature from the filmmaker Chloé Mazlo, “Skies of Lebanon,” is, among other things, an intriguing swing of the pendulum of depiction.

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Karpov
description: Take on Anatoly Karpov in a recreation of a World Championship game in Baguio City, the Philippines, 1978. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.

title: It’s Never Too Late to Learn the Tango and Fall in Love
description: Nancy Cardwell was a successful newspaper editor in New York. Then she took up tango, started spending time in Buenos Aires — and met Luis.

title: Ukrainian troops gain confidence after retaking a village.
description: PAVLIVKA, Ukraine — A sheep dog, padding the streets on his own, was the only sign of life in this destroyed village. Flames licked the rafters of the school and smoke poured out of a burning house several streets away after Russian artillery strikes earlier in the day.

title: How to Make Floral Arrangements That Last and Last
description: For the botanical artist Lutfi Janania, a lush plant isn’t always the right one.
content: When the artist and floral designer Lutfi Janania was a teenager, his parents built a house in a biosphere reserve in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. His father, Omar, a surgeon, oversaw the house’s construction, but he let Janania choose the color of its facade. Janania went with cherry red. “I can’t believe my parents trusted a young gay kid with that decision,” he says from his studio in Brooklyn’s Bushwick neighborhood on a recent afternoon in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford increases its battery supply to meet its electric-vehicle goals.
description: The automaker said it had reached deals to acquire more battery packs in its push to produce 600,000 electric vehicles a year by the end of 2023.
content: Ford Motor said on Thursday that it had reached an agreement to acquire battery packs from a Chinese supplier as it races to ramp up its global production of electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Baltimore Symphony’s New Conductor Breaks a Racial Barrier
description: Jonathon Heyward is the first person of color to be the orchestra’s music director in its 106-year history.
content: For decades, the 25 largest orchestras in the United States have been led almost exclusively by white men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘Anything’s Possible’ Review: Teenagers’ Romance Flowers
description: Self-preservation and allyship are also wrapped up in this sweet young adult romantic comedy, which is Billy Porter’s feature film directorial debut.
content: The high school senior Kelsa (Eva Reign) finds pleasure in discussing the animals she loves on her YouTube channel, seeking comfort in the fact that their names tend to be derived from what makes them unique. The detail sticks out in the actor, singer and author Billy Porter’s pleasant and diverting feature film directorial debut, “Anything’s Possible,” which is now streaming on Amazon Prime. Both intentionally and otherwise, the young adult romantic comedy scuffles with — and tries to unpack the implication of — uniqueness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Gabrielle Zevin Is Not Going to Post This Article
description: The best-selling author of “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow” takes a measured approach to social media. Here’s why.
content: If you visit Gabrielle Zevin’s author website, you will encounter a kind of opacity that is downright refreshing. In lieu of links to Twitter, Facebook, TikTok, Snapchat, YouTube, LinkedIn and so forth, Zevin provides an unusual statement. “I’m allergic to being online, but you will sometimes find me on Instagram, and only for the three months before and after I have a book out,” she writes under the “Contact” tab. “After that time, I completely disappear from the internet and resume writing books again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Carly Olson
title: Jill Biden is keeping her schedule despite close contact with the president.
description: The C.D.C. says people who are up to date with vaccinations don’t need to quarantine after exposure, but should take precautions like wearing a mask around other people.
content: Jill Biden, the first lady, tested negative for the coronavirus in Michigan on Thursday morning, as President Biden tested positive in Washington, D.C.

title: Watchdog Informs Secret Service of Criminal Inquiry Into Missing Texts
description: The Homeland Security Department’s inspector general told the Secret Service to halt its internal investigation into how phone records from around Jan. 6 were purged.
content: WASHINGTON — The inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security directed the Secret Service to halt its internal search for purged texts sent by agents around the time of Jan. 6 so that it does not “interfere with an ongoing criminal investigation,” according to a letter reviewed by The New York Times.

title: Kennedy Center to Honor Gladys Knight, George Clooney, U2 and Others
description: They will be recognized at the 45th ceremony in December along with the composer Tania León and the singer-songwriter Amy Grant.
content: Gladys Knight performed at the Kennedy Center Honors in 2021, paying tribute to one of the honorees, Garth Brooks, with a rendition of his song “We Shall Be Free.” But when she returns to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts this December, she will have a different role: She will be seated in the balcony, wearing a medal designating her as one of this year’s five honorees.

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: I Was Wrong About Chinese Censorship
description: Why was I so sure that economic growth required a free flow of information?
content: Among the most important questions that I’ve wrestled with since becoming a columnist in 1995 are if, when and how fast China will open up its information ecosystem to allow a much freer flow of uncensored news — from both Chinese and foreign sources. I confess that I’ve been too optimistic. I plead guilty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Liz Cheney, Front and Center in the Jan. 6 Hearings, Pursues a Mission
description: “I believe this is the most important thing I’ve ever done professionally,” she said, “and maybe the most important thing I ever do.”
content: The chairman of the House Jan. 6 committee is out with Covid-19. So after giving opening remarks by video when the panel convenes its final scheduled prime-time hearing of the summer on Thursday night, he will turn the gavel over to Representative Liz Cheney. But for all intents and purposes, it has been the Liz Cheney show all along.
